tenses.description: Used for habits, routines, and general truths.
tenses.structure: Subject + base verb (add -s/-es for third-person singular)

exercises.question: She ___ (go) to school every day.
exercises.explanation: In Present Simple, third-person singular subjects (she, he, it) take a verb with -s or -es.

tenses.description: Used for actions happening now or temporary actions.

exercises.question: They ___ (play) football right now.
exercises.explanation: In Present Continuous, use 'are' + verb-ing for plural subjects like 'they'.

tenses.description: Used for past experiences or actions with present relevance.
examples: I have just finished my homework.

exercises.question: I ___ (finish) my homework.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect, use 'have' + past participle for actions completed recently or with present relevance.

tenses.description: Used for actions that started in the past and continue to be relevant in the present.
examples: I have been studying for two hours.
She has been working here since 2019.

exercises.question: She ___ (work) here for five years.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect Continuous, use 'has been' + verb-ing for actions that started in the past and continue in the present.

tenses.description: Used for completed actions in the past.

exercises.question: She ___ (walk) to school yesterday.
exercises.explanation: In Past Simple, use the past form of the verb for actions completed in the past.

tenses.description: Used for actions in progress at a specific time in the past.

exercises.question: They ___ (play) football when it started raining.
exercises.explanation: In Past Continuous, use 'were' + verb-ing for actions in progress in the past.

tenses.description: Used for actions completed before another action in the past.
examples: I had eaten breakfast before I left.

exercises.question: She ___ (finish) her homework before dinner.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect, use 'had' + past participle for actions completed before another past action.

tenses.description: Used for actions that were in progress before another action in the past.
examples: I had been studying for two hours before the exam.
She had been working there for years.

exercises.question: She ___ (work) there for years before she quit.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect Continuous, use 'had been' + verb-ing for actions in progress before another past action.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will happen in the future.

exercises.question: She ___ (visit) Paris next month.
exercises.explanation: In Future Simple, use 'will' + base verb for actions that will happen in the future.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will be in progress at a specific time in the future.
examples: I will be eating lunch at noon.

exercises.question: They ___ (play) football at 5 PM tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: In Future Continuous, use 'will be' + verb-ing for actions in progress in the future.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
examples: I will have finished my homework by 6 PM.

exercises.question: She ___ (visit) Paris by the end of next year.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect, use 'will have' + past participle for actions completed before a future time.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will be in progress up to a specific time in the future.
examples: I will have been studying for two hours by 6 PM.
She will have been working here for five years.

exercises.question: She ___ (work) here for five years by next month.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect Continuous, use 'will have been' + verb-ing for actions in progress up to a future time.
